subject: Re: learning
msgSnippet: Chris, Sound spelling is something that preschoolers have little problem with but adults have to relearn.  In learning tradspel or traditional English
messageBody:
Chris,

Sound spelling is something that preschoolers have little problem
with but adults have to relearn. In learning tradspel or
traditional English orthography you learned most of the 461
different ways to spell 42 phonemes. To learn Quickscript, you only
need to learn 42 for the phonemes plus a few combinations.

Some of the suggestions such as "make flash cards" are quite good.

You might also check out the tiny grapheme-phoneme chart in the file
section of this group.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/gp/readscripts.gif

This can be downloaded and printed.

The three Kingsley Read scripts are Shavian, Quickscript, and
Readscript. The last one is the closest to traditional orthography.

The chart does not include the ASCII version of the fonts. But I am
sure you already have the keyboard equivalents for the Quickskript
font.

I don't quite understand your ah, alms, ox problem. These are all
the same sound /A/. Check your dictionary.

There is a dialect difference in the pronunciation of BOTHER FATHER
but its bAD@r fAD@r in NBC English and bQD@ fAD@ in BBC English.
[notation in SAMPA-IPA]. "on" is probably Q or O and "awl" is O:

In tradspel, <o> is ambivalent shifting bewtween A and O in NBC
English: [olive /A/, moss /O/], on [On], lawn [lO:n].


REF: SAMPA
www.phon.ucl.ac.uk/home/sampa/home.htm

Regards,

Steve

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "branain" <zauniar@n...> wrote:

> Do you have any suggestions on how to learn and practice this
> wonderful writting system?

> I pretty much can grasp all the sounds, but I have a little
problem with the "ah" in "alms" & "ox" sounds. I pronounce them
pretty much the same. I'm from New York, I wonder if that makes a
difference? Is it acceptable to interchange them in my case, as I do
not differentiate between them?

Chris,

Sound spelling is something that preschoolers have little problem 
with but adults have to relearn.  In learning tradspel or 
traditional English orthography you learned most of the 461 
different ways to spell 42 phonemes.  To learn Quickscript, you only 
need to learn 42 for the phonemes plus a few combinations.

Some of the suggestions such as "make flash cards" are quite good.

You might also check out the tiny grapheme-phoneme chart in the file 
section of this group.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/gp/readscripts.gif

This can be downloaded and printed.

The three Kingsley Read scripts are Shavian, Quickscript, and 
Readscript.  The last one is the closest to traditional orthography.

The chart does not include the ASCII version of the fonts.  But I am 
sure you already have the keyboard equivalents for the Quickskript 
font.  

I don't quite understand your ah, alms, ox problem.  These are all 
the same sound /A/. Check your dictionary. 

There is a dialect difference in the pronunciation of BOTHER FATHER 
but its bAD@r fAD@r in NBC English and bQD@ fAD@ in BBC English.  
[notation in SAMPA-IPA].  "on" is probably Q or O and "awl" is O:

In tradspel, <o> is ambivalent shifting bewtween A and O in NBC 
English:  [olive /A/, moss /O/], on [On], lawn [lO:n].


REF: SAMPA
www.phon.ucl.ac.uk/home/sampa/home.htm

Regards,

Steve
